Evaluating Discards using Observer Data Guyana`s Shrimp Fishery Seion Richardson | sar21@hi.is 2020-12-30 1 CHAPTER 1.1 Key definitions Total catch - the amount of fish caught by a fishing gear that reaches the vessels deck. Target catch - the main species which are sought after by a particular fishery e.g. cod or shrimp. Incidental catch - the species caught which are retained for consumption or marketing purposes. Discarded catch - the section of catch returned to the sea, usually dead or alive. Bycatch - Discarded catch combined with incidental catch. Fishery observer - is a specialist trained in collecting data onboard commercial fishing vessels. Observer data - data collected at-sea by fishery observers. Tow - The act of fishing or trawling. CPUE - Catch per unit effort i.e. the fish caught per unit of fishing effort e.g. kgs/hr. 1.2 Introduction The data used in this project is on discarded fish species (Appendix 5.2) from the Atlantic seabob (Appendix 5.3) fishery in Guyana, South America (Figure 1.1). The data was collected at-sea by fishery observers (Figure 1.2) onboard seven Atlantic seabob shrimp bottom trawl vessels (Appendix 5.1) between 2019 to 2020 (see chapter 1.3 for data variables). The data was collected within the seabob trawling zone i.e. 15 to 33 metres of water depth (Figure 1.1). It includes sampled bottom trawl fishing tow data from eight distinct fishing trips (one vessel was used twice) with an average of six sampled hauls per trip (three day, three night) and at different fishing depths (shallow, deep). Time of day are split into day (6:00HRS to 17:59HRS) and night (18:00HRS to 5:59HRS). Fishing depths are split into deep (> 16.46 metres) and shallow (<= 16.46 metres) of water depths. Based on interactions with fisherfolks in Guyana, discarding of fish species from Guyana`s main shrimp fishery is said to be excessive. Therefore this issue will be closely examined in this project, with specific emphasis on species weights and lengths; across varying time of day and fishing depths. Description of data variables The variables within the data are coded. A total of 32 variables were recorded in the data. A description for each variable is below : company: Fishing company dep_date: Date the vessel departs port for fishing arr_date: Date the vessel returns from fishing das: Number of days the vessel spent at-sea trip: Unique trip identification number drag: Unique drag identification number by drag_all: Sequential drag identification number drag_date: Date the drag was done day: Day the drag was done month: Month the drag was done year: Year the drag was done zone: Fishing zone (Figure 1) where the drag was done drag_period: Binary variable of time of day for drag drag_time_s: Time the drag started (24:00 hrs) drag_time_e: Time the drag ended (24:00 hrs) time_fished_min: Time fished in hours hrs_dec: Time fished converted to decimals depth: Average fishing depth depth_sd: Binary variable of fishing depth id_status: Binary variable of species identification com_status: Binary variable of species economic status order: Species taxonomy - Order family: Species taxonomy - Family class: Species taxonomy - Class total_catch_cat: Catch categorization (see definitions) total_catch_spp: Board species categorization categories: More narrow species categorization sci_name: Latin names for each species alpha_code: Unique 3-alpha species identifier used by FAO com_name: Local name or call name for species sample_wt_lbs: Species sample weight per drag (in lbs) total_wt_lbs: Species total weight per drag (in lbs) However, most of them will not be required in this project. After reviewing the data we now look at the research objective, questions and hypotheses 1.5 Objective To determine the extent of discarding within Guyana`s Atlantic seabob shrimp fishery. This will be done using observer data to evaluate the weights and lengths of the discarded species across dissimilar time of day (day, night) and fishing depths (deep, shallow). More precisely this study will aim to answer the following questions: 1.5.1 Research Questions 1.5.1.1 First Submission What are the weights by the different catch categories and what proportions of the catch are discarded? What are the species discarded, their relative sampling proportions and weights? 1.5.1.2 Second Submission What are the weight distributions of the most common (by weight) discarded fish species across time of day and fishing depths? Are the mean weights for the discarded fish species (ALL) equal across time of day and fishing depths? 1.5.1.3 Third Submission (Joining Weights and Lengths data) What were the length distributions of the most common (by lengths) discarded fish species across time of day and fishing depths? Are the mean lengths for the discarded fish species (ALL) equal across time of day and fishing depths? 1.5.2 Hypotheses \(H_O\) (Null hypothesis)  Mean species weights are equal across time of day and fishing depths. \(H_A\) (Alternate hypothesis) - Mean species weights are not equal across time of day and fishing depths. \(H_O\) (Null hypothesis)  Mean species lengths are equal across time of day and fishing depths. \(H_A\) (Alternate hypothesis)  Mean species lengths are not equal across time of day and fishing depths.

2 CHAPTER 2.1 Research Question 1 What are the weights by the different catch categories and what proportions of the catch are discarded? First we will look at proportions by the different catch categories 2.1.1 Catch categories ggplot(data = ObserverData, mapping = aes(x = as.factor(TripID), y = TotalWeightKG, fill = SpeciesCategory2)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") + theme_bw() + theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", colour = "grey50"), legend.position = "none") + labs(x="Observer trips", y = "Discarded catch (kgs)") + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") + facet_wrap(. ~ SpeciesCategory2) Figure 2.1: Barplots showing a breakdown of weights by species category across fishing trips ### CODE COMMENTS ### #[1]. Here the Observerdata is used to get the four categories of species caught and to plot # them using using four bar plots on a single window using facet_wrap(). #[2]. The first argument to ggplot() is the data ("ObserverData"). Then the mapping = aes() where # the X variable ("TripID") and the Y variable "TotalWeightKG" were supplied. #[3]. The fill argument is used to colour the data by the different categories i.e. "SpeciesCategory2". #[4]. The arguments were passed to geom_bar(). #[5]. The plot is formatted using theme() and the legend removed using the legend.position argument. # Because the names were provide by facet_wrap() a legend would have been redundant. #[6]. X and Y axis labels were added using labs(). #[7]. The scale_fill_brewer is used to customize the color of the bars according to the # species category. The palette argument is used within the function to achieve this. #[8]. facet_wrap() is used to complete the figure. In total 18,608 kgs of fish were landed. Of this amount, bony fish accounted for the highest i.e. 8,804 kgs, followed by shellfish (7,240 kgs), flatfish (1,938 kgs) and others (626 kgs) (Figure 2.1). A similar trend is seen in the mean weights caught per trip for the different categories i.e. bony fish the highest 1,101 kgs/trip, followed by shell fish (905 kgs/trip), flat fish 242 kgs/trip and Others 78 kgs/trip. The minimum and maximum discard landed by category are as follows: bony fish discards ranged from 683 kgs (trip 4) to 2,410 kgs (trip 6), shell fish from 346 kgs (trip 7) to 1,885 kgs (trip 4), flat fish from 18 kgs (trip 1) to 577 kgs (trip 6) and others from 9 kgs to 257 kgs (trip 6) (Figure 2.1). Now we will look at the proportions of the catch discarded 2.1.2 Proportions of the catch discarded This will be looked at across fishing trips FilteredCatch <- ObserverData %>% filter(CatchCategory == "Discarded catch" | CatchCategory == "Target catch") SumFilteredCatch <- FilteredCatch %>% group_by(TripID, SpeciesCategory) %>% dplyr::summarise(WeightKG = sum(TotalWeightKG), .groups = 'drop') %>% group_by(TripID) %>% mutate(Percentage = round(prop.table(WeightKG)*100)) ggplot(data = SumFilteredCatch, mapping = aes(x = SpeciesCategory, y = Percentage, fill = SpeciesCategory)) + geom_col(position = "dodge", width = 0.9) + theme_bw() + theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", colour = "grey50"), axis.text.x = element_blank(), axis.ticks.x = element_blank(), legend.position = "bottom") + labs(x="Fishing Trips", y = "Percentages (%)") + scale_fill_brewer(palette="Set2", name = " ", labels = c("Discarded catch", "Target catch")) + facet_grid(cols = vars(TripID)) Figure 2.2: Barplot showing a breakdown of weights (proportions) by catch category for the different fishing trips. The numbers at the top of each pair of bars i.e. in the grey area represents the Fishing Trip number ID ### CODE COMMENTS ### #[1]. Filtering the observer data by catch category. #[2]. Creating a summary table of weights by fishing trip and species category. #[3]. group_by() and summarise() are used to obtain this along with sum() to create a # variable called "WeightKG". #[4]. The names argument is used # to remove the default name and replace with a blank space (" ") and the labels argument # to add labels to the plot. #[8]. fact_grid() is used to present the data side-by-side by fishing trips. Of the total fish weight, discarded catch accounted for 11,956 kgs (68%) and target species 5,705 kgs (32%) (Figure 2.2). Discarded catch proportions (by weight) within the total catch ranged from 37% (trip 4) to 95% (trip 6). Target catch on the other hand ranged from 5% (trip 6) to 63% (trip 4) (Figure 2.2). 2.1.3 Assessment summary The data comprised of four different catch categories: bony fish, shell fish, flat fish and others. From the analysis done bony fish accounted to the highest total weights within the data and least was recorded by the others category. Discarding of fish species was found to relatively high (i.e. 68%) when compared to that of the target catch (32%). With the exception of fishing trip 1 and 4, the total weights of the discarded fish species was always higher than that of the target catch. 2.2 Research Question 2 What are the species discarded, their relative sampling proportions and weights? 2.2.1 Species discarded and their relative sampling proportions Table.2.1 <- DiscardData %>% group_by(OrderTax, FamilyTax, LatinNames) %>% dplyr::summarise(n = n(), prop = round(n/48,2), .groups = 'drop') %>% arrange(OrderTax) Table.2.1$OrderTax = ifelse(duplicated(Table.2.1$OrderTax), "", Table.2.1$OrderTax) Table.2.1$FamilyTax = ifelse(duplicated(Table.2.1$FamilyTax), "", Table.2.1$FamilyTax) Table.2.1 %>% kbl(caption = "Fish taxa identified from the 48 bottom trawl fishing tows sampled off the coast of Guyana. The data presented in this paragraph and the figure above is filtered to remove those species which occurred less than 5 times in the sample (Figure 2.3). The top five species by median weight landed were: Polymixia lowei (18 kgs), followed by Stellifer rastrifer, Stellifer microps, Macrodon ancylodon and Larimus breviceps all with 14 kgs, respectively. The weight range for these species are as follows: Polymixia lowei (7 to 21 kgs), Stellifer rastrifer (1 to 164 kgs), Stellifer microps (1 to 133 kgs), Macrodon ancylodon (1 to 74 kgs) and Larimus breviceps (1 to 61 kgs). The five species with the lowest median weights were: Mustelus higmani (1 kg), followed by Sphoeroides testudineus, Persephona lichtensteinii, Chaetodipterus faber and Hepatus gronovii all with 2 kgs. The weight range for these species are as follows: Mustelus higmani (0.2 to 33 kgs), followed by Sphoeroides testudineus (0.1 to 26 kgs), Persephona lichtensteinii (0.005 to 14 kgs), Chaetodipterus faber (0.01 to 21 kgs) and Hepatus gronovii (0.3 to 14 kgs) (Figure 2.3). 2.2.3 Assessment summary From the analysis it was found that 61 different species (i.e. those positively identified) were discarded (Table 2.1). Of this amount four of them: Callinectes ornatus, Macrodon ancylodon, Stellifer microps and Stellifer rastrifer were in at least 45 of the 48 total bottom trawl tows. The latter three fish species, along with Polymixia lowei and Larimus breviceps were the most dominant species discarded by median weights.

To see a description of the functions used in this code and how they work please refer # to the code comments made at Table.3.1 Of the total discard fish species weights (5,403 kgs) for the top 6 fish species, 52% (2,835 kgs) were recorded for the day and 48% (2,568 kgs) for the night (Table 3.2). This means that the cumulative fish species weights were marginally higher in the day when compared to the night. Further, we see that the total weights by fish species in the day ranged from 170 kgs(Nebris microps) to 765 kgs(Stellifer rastrifer). Whereas the total weights in the night ranged from 54 kgs (Trichiurus lepturus) to 806 kgs (Stellifer rastrifer). From Figure 3.3 and Table 3.2 we see that Trichiurus lepturus had the lowest median weights across time of day i.e. 4 kgs (day) and 1 kg (night) for the top 6 fish species examined. While Stellifer rastrifer recorded the highest median weights for both the day (37 kgs) and night (30 kgs). Therefore, we can conclude that Stellifer rastrifer was the most dominant discarded fish species across time of day with the highest individual total weight and median, while Nebris microps and Trichiurus lepturus were the least dominant discarded fish species i.e. recording the lowest total weight and median, respectively, across time of day. 3.1.4 Assessment of fish species weights across fishing depths 3.1.4.1 Box plots of the distribution for the six (6) most common (by weights) fish species discarded across fishing depths. ggplot(Top.6.fish.data, aes(x = LatinNames, y = TotalWeightKG, colour = LatinNames)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5) + stat_boxplot(geom = 'errorbar', width = 0.2) + theme_bw() + theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", colour = "grey50"), axis.text.x = element_blank(), axis.ticks.x = element_blank(), legend.title = element_blank(), legend.position = "bottom", legend.text = element_text(face = "italic")) + labs(x = "Latin names of fish species", y = "Weights (kgs)") + facet_wrap(.~FishingDepth2) Figure 3.4: Boxplot of discarded fish species weights by fishing depths. From Figure 3.4 and Table 3.3 we see that Trichiurus lepturus had the lowest median weights across fishing depths i.e. 2 kgs (deep) and 4 kgs (shallow) for the top 6 fish species examined. While Stellifer rastrifer recorded the highest median weights for both the deep (30 kgs) and shallow (34 kgs). Therefore, we can conclude that Stellifer rastrifer was the most dominant discarded fish species across fishing depths with the highest total wight and median, while Trichiurus lepturus was the least dominant discarded fish species i.e. recording the lowest total weight and median across fishing depths. 3.1.5 Assessment summary In summary, of the top 6 species examined across time of day and fishing depths we found that Stellifer rastrifer was always the main discarded species whereas Trichiurus lepturus was often the least discarded species amongst the top six species looked at. 3.2 Research Question 4 Are the mean weights for the discarded fish species (ALL) equal across time of day and fishing depths? Test assumptions This test assumes that the the weight observations across time of day (day/night) and fishing depths (deep/shallow) are normally distributed. Fortunately as well, this method is not at all sensitive to deviations from this assumption. Therefore, if the distributions of day/night or deep/shallow are the same e.g. if both distributions are skewed to the right. This example is the case with this data as seen earlier. This means that the analysis will be performed on the actual weights variable and no transformation is needed. This assumption was tested in this project and the results indeed were almost identical How the Welch Two Sample t-test works The test statistic, \(t_s\), is computed using a method that has the difference between the means in the numerator. This therefore makes the \(t_s\) larger as the means move away from each other. The standard error of the difference in the means in this case is denominator. This value decreases as the sample variances decreases or if the size of sample increase. Hence the \(t_s\) gets larger as the means move further apart, the variances get smaller, or if the size of the sample increase. The probability of getting the observed \(t_s\) value under the null hypothesis is computed using the t-distribution. Conducting the t-tests 3.2.2.1 Time of day # Welch t.test - time of day Weight.ttest.TP <- t.test(TotalWeightKG ~ TimePeriods, data = Discard.data) Weight.ttest.TP Welch Two Sample t-test data: TotalWeightKG by TimePeriods t = 0.89664, df = 1056.3, p-value = 0.3701 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -0.9953903 2.6705615 sample estimates: mean in group Day mean in group Night 9.370018 8.532433 ### CODE COMMENTS ### #[1]. The "DiscardData" is passed to t.test(). #[2]. t.test() is used to analyze the "TotalWeightKG" variable against time of day. The p-value associated with the test is \(0.37\), so we fail to reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) of no difference between the (true) means of the two groups (i.e. time of day; day and night) since the p-value is greater than the usual significance level \(alpha = 0.05\). Therefore we conclude based on this data, that there is not enough evidence of a difference between the (true) means of the two groups at the usual significance level of \(alpha = 0.05\). 3.2.2.2 Fishing depths # Welch t.test - fishing depths Weight.ttest.FD <- t.test(TotalWeightKG ~ FishingDepth2, data = Discard.data) Weight.ttest.FD Welch Two Sample t-test data: TotalWeightKG by FishingDepth2 t = 0.39181, df = 1050.8, p-value = 0.6953 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -1.461899 2.191380 sample estimates: mean in group Deep mean in group Shallow 9.163561 8.798821 ### CODE COMMENTS ### #[1]. To see a description of what the functions in this code are doing please refer to # the code comments at Weight.ttest.TP. The only exception is "FishingDepth2" # have replaced "TimePeriods". The p-value associated with the test is \(0.70\), so we fail to reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) of no difference between the (true) means of the two groups (i.e. fishing depths; deep and shallow) since the p-value is greater than the usual significance level \(alpha = 0.05\). Therefore we conclude based on this data, that there is not enough evidence of a difference between the (true) means of the two groups at the usual significance level of \(alpha = 0.05\). 3.2.3 Analysis summary In summary, from the analysis of the discarded species (ALL) from the data, we found that there is not enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) which is that the means are equal across time of day and fishing depths. This was proven by the high p-values (\(> 0.05\)) obtained from the Welch Two Sample t-tests conducted on the discard species data across time of day and fishing depths. 3.3 Closing remarks Chapter 3 was focused on the weight analysis of discarded fish species. In Chapter 4, the focus will shift to the length analysis of discarded fish species. To achieve this a separate dataset will be joined to the data which was used in this Chapter. This will be required to answer Research Questions 5 & 6. For more details please see Chapter 1 - sub-chapter 1.5.

This finding was surprising and concerning. In my personal opinion discarding of fish of any size should be disincentivised/disallowed as it is a wastage of valuable marine resources. 4.2 Research Question 6 Are the mean lengths for the discarded fish species (ALL) equal across time of day and fishing depths? To answer this research question we will now look at the discard fish species - length data for all fish species. This will help us to get an idea of how the lengths are distributed for the entire population and not just a subsample of the data which we used to answer Research Question 5. The following hypothesis will be tested \(H_O\) (Null hypothesis)  Mean species lengths are equal across time of day and fishing depths. \(H_A\) (Alternate hypothesis) - Mean species lengths are not equal across time of day and fishing depths. The lengths for the fish species plotted ranged from 2 cm to 38 cm in the deep and 3 cm to 31 cm in the shallow. The mean length for the discarded fish species is lower in the deep (12.4 cm), in comparison to the shallow (13.2 cm). The standard deviations for the means are 5.3 cm (deep) and 5.2 cm (shallow). Having viewed the data, we will now run some statistical tests to test the hypotheses 4.2.2 Analysis of the mean lengths for discarded fish species across time of day and fishing depths using the Welch Two Sample t-test. Test assumptions This test assumes that the the length observations across time of day (day/night) and fishing depths (deep/shallow) are normally distributed. Fortunately as well, this method is not at all sensitive to deviations from this assumption. Therefore, if the distributions of day/night or deep/shallow are the same e.g. if both distributions are skewed to the right/left. As seen from the histograms (Figures 4.6 and 4.7), the length distribution fits this expectation nicely. Therefore, the analysis will be performed on the actual length variable and no transformation will be required. As a precautionary measure, this assumption was also tested in chapter 3.2.2 and proven to be accurate How the Welch Two Sample t-test works The test statistic, \(t_s\), is computed using a method that has the difference between the means in the numerator. This therefore makes the \(t_s\) larger as the means move away from each other. The standard error of the difference in the means in this case is denominator. This value decreases as the sample variances decreases or if the size of sample increase. Hence the \(t_s\) gets larger as the means move further apart, the variances get smaller, or if the size of the sample increase. The probability of getting the observed \(t_s\) value under the null hypothesis is computed using the t-distribution. Conducting the t-tests 4.2.2.1 Time of day # Welch t.test - time of day length.ttest.tp <- t.test(Lengths ~ TimePeriods, data = LengthData) length.ttest.tp Welch Two Sample t-test data: Lengths by TimePeriods t = 1.619, df = 3217.7, p-value = 0.1055 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -0.07743775 0.81125088 sample estimates: mean in group Day mean in group Night 13.40032 13.03342 ### CODE COMMENTS ### #[1]. The "LengthData" is passed to t.test(). #[2]. t.test() is used to analyze the "Lengths" variable against time of day. The p-value associated with the test is \(0.10\), so we fail to reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) of no difference between the (true) means of the two groups (i.e. time of day; day and night) since the p-value is greater than the usual significance level \(alpha = 0.05\). Therefore we conclude based on this data, that there is not enough evidence of a difference between the (true) means of the two groups at the usual significance level of \(alpha = 0.05\). We now repeat the test for fishing depths 4.2.2.2 Fishing depths # Welch t.test - fishing depths length.ttest.fd <- t.test(Lengths ~ FishingDepth2, data = LengthData) length.ttest.fd Welch Two Sample t-test data: Lengths by FishingDepth2 t = -7.022, df = 2997.8, p-value = 2.695e-12 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -2.073593 -1.168343 sample estimates: mean in group Deep mean in group Shallow 12.41628 14.03725 ### CODE COMMENTS ### #[1]. To see a description of what the functions in this code are doing please refer to # the code comments at length.ttest.tp. The only exception is "FishingDepth2" # have replaced "TimePeriods". The p-value associated with the test is \(2.695e-12\), therefore we reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) of there being no difference between the (true) means of the two groups (i.e. fishing depths; deep and shallow) since the p-value is lesser than the usual significance level \(alpha = 0.05\). Therefore we conclude based on this data, that there is enough evidence of a difference between the (true) means of the two groups at the usual significance level of \(alpha = 0.05\). 4.2.3 Analysis summary In summary, from the analysis of the discarded species (ALL) across time of day, we found that there is not enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) of the means being equal across time of day. This was proven by the high p-value (\(> 0.05\)) obtained from the Welch Two Sample t-tests conducted on the discarded species data across time of day. On the other hand, we did find (based on the data) that there is enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) of the means being equal across fishing depths. This was proven by the low p-value (\(> 0.05\)) obtained from the Welch Two Sample t-tests conducted on the discard species data across fishing depths. 4.3 Final remarks Chapter 4 was focused on a Length Analysis of the discarded fish species caught offshore Guyana. To achieve this a separate dataset LengthImport containing length measurements was Joined to the original data Discard.data used in Chapter 3 which contained the weight measurements for the Weight Analysis.
